author: jasonf

comments.content: Looks like Eurostile Bold Extended #2, gussied up of course.

I’d say [Microgramma Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007180601/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/urw/microgramma_extended_bold/&sample_text=GATOR&sample_size=36). [edit] and extended, of course.
I am still trying to get a feel for kerning, so I am wondering...do the experienced eyes think the AT could use some adjustment?

Definitely!

PS: I believe Eurostile, which originated in the early 1960s, is a more comprehensive version of Microgramma, which was an all caps font dating back to the early 1950s. As I recall, the same Swiss designers worked on both.

malbright wrote: _As I recall, the same **Swiss designers** worked on both._.

The design came from [Aldo Novarese](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007180601/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aldo_Novarese), an **Italian type designer**. More information at the wikipedia link …
Apart from that, Michael has it right. Eurostile is Microgramma with lowercase and extra weights.
Oops. Did I saw Swiss? I meant Italian. ;-0
Why changing the name of a font when lowercase characters are added? Do font names change when cyrillic characters are added?

_\>Why changing the name of a font when lowercase characters are added?_

Marketing! When Eurostile was brought out, it was a new type family. They still kept selling Microgramma, as far as I know. More type families in the catalog can often lead to more sales.

_\>Do font names change when cyrillic characters are added?_

No. Sometimes, the name might be appended with a “Pro” or “Plus” or “Super” or “Awesome” or “Whatever” though.

Here is what I gathered from the [Eurostile](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007180601/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=eurostile++&x=19&y=15) and [Microgramma](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007180601/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=microgramma+&x=18&y=10) fonts on FontShop:

- Both have lowercase characters
- Elsner+Flake sells Microgramma in 2 styles: extended medium and extended bold
- URW sells Microgramma in 3 styles: extended medium, extended bold and extended bold shadow
- Linotype Library sells Eurostile in 10 styles (with condensed and normal, an additional demi weight, and italics)

and I have the feeling I am still missing part of the story.

And looking for Microgramma [**here**](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007180601/http:/www.paratype.com/asearch/default.asp?search=microgramma&params=1&x=12&y=6) (paratype.com), I found “Magistral” and “Micra” with cyrillic characters and saw [Square 721](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007180601/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=square+721&x=0&y=0&sample_text=GATOR&sample_size=36) in the list...

[edit] Moreover, looking for Eurostile on the same site, I found [**Europe**](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007180601/http:/www.paratype.com/pstore/default.asp?fcode=TM_ERP&letter=E) with plenty of styles, and cyrillic characters. It is said: _The typeface was designed at TypeMarket in 1992-1993 by Alexey Kustov. Similar to Eurostile by Aldo Novarese, 1962, Nebiolo._ [note: The character set is just cyrillic standard].
Ahhh, the wonders of clones, competing type foundries and the confusion they create. ;^)
